title: Non-REM Parasomnias
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of non-REM parasomnias (disorders of arousal) in adults. Covers sleepwalking (somnambulism), sleep terrors (pavor nocturnus), confusional arousals, and related variants including sleep-related eating disorder and sexsomnia. Critical focus on differentiating from nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy. Includes diagnostic workup, safety interventions, trigger management, and pharmacotherapy. Excludes REM sleep behavior disorder (separate plan), nightmare disorder, and pediatric-specific management.

Safety and Environmental Interventions (.indication: Injury prevention during sleepwalking/sleep terror episodes

dosing.instructions: Lock windows and exterior doors; install door alarms or motion-sensor alarms; remove sharp objects and breakable items from bedroom; place mattress on floor or use bed rails; lock away weapons and car keys; install gates on stairways; secure glass doors and windows

Safety and Environmental Interventions (.indication: Prevent injury to bed partner during violent episodes

dosing.instructions: Consider separate sleeping arrangements if episodes involve violent or sexual behaviors; educate partner not to forcefully restrain (may worsen agitation); gently redirect patient back to bed without attempting to wake

Safety and Environmental Interventions (.indication: Reduce fall risk during ambulatory parasomnias

dosing.instructions: Place mattress directly on floor; remove bedframe; clear area around bed of obstacles and hard furniture

Safety and Environmental Interventions (.indication: Capture events for diagnostic characterization; assess safety of environment

dosing.instructions: Infrared/night-vision camera in bedroom; record events for clinical review; assists in differentiating from seizures (stereotypy vs. variable behavior)

Trigger Management — Non-Pharmacologic (.indication: Sleep deprivation is the single strongest trigger for NREM parasomnias

dosing.instructions: Regular sleep-wake schedule 7 days/week; target 7-9 hours nightly; avoid sleep deprivation; cool, dark, quiet sleeping environment; limit screen time 1 hour before bed; avoid shift work if possible

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: First-line when parasomnia episodes pose safety risk; suppresses arousals from slow-wave sleep; most evidence for NREM parasomnias

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg at bedtime; titrate by 0.25 mg every 1-2 weeks based on response; effective range 0.25-2 mg; max 2 mg qHS; taper slowly to discontinue (rebound parasomnias possible)

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; untreated OSA (respiratory depression risk); pregnancy (teratogenic); concurrent opioids or heavy alcohol use; myasthenia gravis
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Sedation; tolerance; daytime somnolence; falls risk (especially elderly); respiratory function; rebound parasomnias on discontinuation; abuse potential

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Safe first-line option; consolidates NREM sleep architecture; preferred in elderly or when benzodiazepines contraindicated

dosing.instructions: Start 3 mg 30 minutes before bedtime; may increase by 3 mg every 1-2 weeks; max 9 mg; extended-release formulation may be more effective for maintaining consolidated sleep

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Daytime sedation; headache; vivid dreams; next-day grogginess at higher doses

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Sleep terrors specifically; SSRI may reduce NREM parasomnia frequency; limited evidence

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg at bedtime; may increase to 20 mg after 2 weeks; evidence primarily for sleep terrors

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; concurrent pimozide or thioridazine; first trimester pregnancy
Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Serotonin syndrome; sexual dysfunction; weight gain; discontinuation symptoms if stopped abruptly; suicidality monitoring in young adults; paradoxical worsening of parasomnias (rare)

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Concurrent insomnia with parasomnia; reduces NREM arousals; sedating antidepressant

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg at bedtime; titrate by 25 mg every 1-2 weeks; max 100 mg qHS for parasomnia indication

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent QT-prolonging drugs
Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Priapism (rare but serious); orthostatic hypotension; next-day sedation; cardiac arrhythmia at higher doses

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Refractory sleep terrors; tricyclic antidepressant with evidence for sleep terrors

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg at bedtime; titrate by 10-25 mg every 1-2 weeks; max 50 mg qHS; avoid in elderly (anticholinergic burden, falls risk)

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Recent MI; concurrent MAOIs; cardiac conduction disease; narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; elderly (relative)
Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: ECG before starting and with dose increases; anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention); orthostatic hypotension; weight gain; QTc prolongation

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Sleep-related eating disorder variant of NREM parasomnia; dual benefit if comorbid migraine

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg at bedtime; titrate by 25 mg every 1-2 weeks; target 50-100 mg; max 100 mg qHS for SRED

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Metabolic acidosis; nephrolithiasis; pregnancy (teratogenic — cleft palate); hepatic failure
Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Metabolic acidosis (serum bicarbonate); kidney stones; cognitive effects (word-finding difficulty); weight loss; paresthesias; glaucoma symptoms

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Increases slow-wave sleep stability; useful if concurrent neuropathic pain or RLS; reduces NREM arousal frequency

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg at bedtime; titrate by 300 mg every 3-5 days; max 900 mg qHS; renal dose adjustment required

Second-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; weight gain; respiratory depression if combined with CNS depressants; renal function

Referrals & Consults.item: Sleep medicine specialist for video-PSG scheduling, diagnosis confirmation, identification of comorbid sleep disorders (OSA, RLS/PLMD), and long-term pharmacotherapy management

Neurology / epilepsy specialist to differentiate from nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy (sleep-related hypermotor epilepsy) when events are stereotyped, brief, frequent, or occur multiple times per night
Psychiatry referral if significant psychological stress, trauma, anxiety, or comorbid mood disorder is contributing to parasomnia frequency or severity
Forensic sleep medicine evaluation if parasomnia events have medicolegal implications (violence during sleep, sexsomnia, injury to others, sleep-driving)
ENT / pulmonology if obstructive sleep apnea identified as arousal trigger requiring CPAP titration or surgical evaluation

Patient/Family Instructions.item: NREM parasomnias are a neurological condition caused by incomplete arousals from deep sleep; they are not a psychiatric disorder or sign of emotional disturbance
Safety-proof the sleeping environment immediately: lock doors and windows, install alarms, remove sharp objects, place mattress on floor, secure weapons and car keys
Do NOT forcefully restrain or attempt to aggressively wake someone during an episode; this may worsen agitation and risk injury; instead, gently guide the person back to bed and speak calmly
Report any injuries to self or others occurring during episodes; escalating frequency, increasing violence, or new behaviors require urgent medical reassessment
Avoid sleep deprivation — this is the single strongest trigger; maintain a consistent sleep schedule even on weekends and holidays
Avoid alcohol within 3 hours of bedtime; alcohol is a potent trigger for NREM parasomnias
Bed partners should sleep in a separate room if episodes involve violent or sexual behaviors until treatment is effective
Record events on video (smartphone with night vision or infrared camera) whenever safely possible; video recordings are extremely valuable for diagnosis

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain strict consistent sleep-wake schedule 7 days per week; sleep deprivation is the most potent and modifiable trigger for NREM parasomnias
Stress reduction techniques including mindfulness, progressive muscle relaxation, or cognitive behavioral therapy; psychological stress increases NREM sleep instability
Avoid alcohol within 3 hours of bedtime; alcohol fragments NREM sleep and lowers the arousal threshold
Regular moderate exercise (30 minutes daily) promotes consolidated sleep; avoid vigorous exercise within 2 hours of bedtime
Avoid heavy meals within 2 hours of bedtime; large meals may disrupt sleep architecture and increase arousals
Review all medications with provider; common triggers include zolpidem, SSRIs, lithium, quetiapine, sodium oxybate, and beta-blockers
Avoid shift work when possible; irregular sleep schedules are a significant trigger for disorders of arousal
Treat comorbid sleep disorders (OSA with CPAP, RLS with appropriate therapy) as these increase the arousal burden that triggers parasomnia events

differential.diagnosis: Nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy (NFLE) / Sleep-related hypermotor epilepsy (SHE)
differential.features: KEY DIFFERENTIAL: highly stereotyped events; brief duration (typically <2 min); multiple events per night possible; hypermotor semiology (kicking, pedaling, thrashing); may retain awareness; can occur at any time of night; events cluster in NREM stage 2
differential.tests: Video-PSG with extended EEG montage; routine EEG (may show frontal spikes/sharp waves); MRI brain (frontal cortical dysplasia); trial of carbamazepine (positive response supports epilepsy)

differential.features: Occurs during REM sleep (second half of night); dream enactment with recall of vivid/violent dreams; typically older males >50; REM without atonia on PSG; associated with alpha-synucleinopathies (Parkinson, DLB, MSA)
differential.tests: Video-PSG showing REM without atonia; clinical history of dream recall and REM-timing events

differential.diagnosis: Obstructive sleep apnea with confusional arousals
differential.features: Pseudo-parasomnia triggered by respiratory arousals; snoring, witnessed apneas, obesity; events resolve with CPAP treatment
differential.tests: PSG with respiratory scoring (AHI >5); trial of CPAP with resolution of events

differential.features: Full awakening with complete recall; subjective terror with palpitations, dyspnea, chest pain; daytime panic attacks also present; occurs from NREM stage 2-3 but patient is fully alert after
differential.tests: Psychiatric evaluation; presence of daytime panic disorder; full recall of event (vs. amnesia in parasomnias)

differential.features: Dream recall present; REM-associated; history of trauma; nightmares with thematic content related to traumatic experiences; full arousal with emotional recall
differential.tests: Psychiatric evaluation; trauma history; PSG shows events arise from REM; dream content recall

differential.features: Events arise from established wakefulness (not from sleep); normal EEG during events; prolonged episodes; history of trauma/abuse; events may occur with eyes open during wakefulness in bed
differential.tests: Video-PSG showing events arise from documented wakefulness (alpha EEG rhythm); psychiatric evaluation

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication initiation or dose change; common culprits: zolpidem (sleepwalking, sleep-driving), SSRIs, lithium, quetiapine, sodium oxybate
differential.tests: Medication review; temporal correlation; resolution with dose reduction or discontinuation

differential.features: Diaphoresis, confusion, tremor; occurs in diabetic patients on insulin or sulfonylureas; blood glucose <70 mg/dL during events
differential.tests: Continuous glucose monitoring; fingerstick glucose during or immediately after event

differential.features: Prolonged confusional wandering; may have subtle ictal features (automatisms, lip smacking); postictal confusion
differential.tests: EEG during event showing seizure activity; response to antiseizure medications
